awd_titl_txt: Novel Virtual Element Methods with Applications in Interface Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Interface problems arise from many important complex multiphysics and biological systems, such as those involving the evolutions of multi-fluid/material interfaces, tumor growth, or stem cell deformation. Computer-aided simulation is a cost-friendly tool for the studies of these challenging interface problems. To approximate the governing mathematical equations of these systems, Virtual element method (VEM) is an emerging powerful tool in the scientific computing community. The objective of this research project is to develop both theoretical and practical aspects of various VEMs. Being able to reliably answer the question "can we trust our simulation results?" justifies the use of VEMs in simulating these complex systems. Meanwhile, this project strives to provide the public with a state-of-the-art VEM computer program that saves valuable computing resources. In addition, this research project creates opportunities to pass the torch on to graduate students to become the next generation computational mathematicians.

Solving elliptic partial differential equations with high-contrast diffusion coefficients play a central role in the modeling these complex systems. This project shall develop an in-depth robust a priori error analysis of VEM on elliptic interface problems. Different from the existing VEM analysis, this project devises a new novel paradigm to study the error analysis for the interface VEM, and further clarifies the dependence of the VEM convergence on the polytopal mesh geometries, justifying the VEM's applicability on interface-fitted mesh which may become extremely irregular or degenerate near the interfaces. Meanwhile, this project learns from the novelty of VEM framework to improve the analyses of traditional approaches for interface problems. The VEM's meta-formulation for elliptic problems enables us to construct immersed finite element spaces naturally in higher order and/or in 3-D.  Higher order interface VEMs, the a posteriori error estimation, and the adaptive polytopal mesh refinement are to be studied to render VEM more efficient and effective. This integrated study enables us to attack the challenging 3-D interface problems, which, in turn, broadens the scope in terms of both theory and tools for the whole numerical partial differential equation community. Last but not least, a portable and highly-vectorized VEM software library shall be made publicly available, including the semi-structured interface-fitted mesh generation, vectorized assembling, polytopal adaptivity, and fast multigrid solvers. The portability of the computer code enables the researchers to incorporate the VEM into existing software libraries dealing with interface problems, thus facilitating the interdisciplinary research in simulating those complex systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has performed an integrated study on virtual element methods (VEM) driven by how to solve elliptic interface problems efficiently and robustly, especially with respect to the geometric intricacies caused by the interface cutting the elements in the mesh. The a priori error analysis is conducted for conforming and nonconforming VEM approximations.
The a posterior error estimation and an adaptive polytopal mesh refinement strategy on
quadtree-type quadrilateral meshes are proposed. A novel two-grid solver and a multilevel preconditioning strategy are proposed for the VEM discretization of the H(curl)-interface problems that arise from eddy current simulation. This project also updated the VEM subroutines in the publicly available open-source software package iFEM on GitHub, as well as implemented finite element methods in PyTorch to take advantage of the auto-differentiation, to facilitate the research in various science and engineering applications.
This project also contributes to the analysis and implementation of several nonconforming/hybridized finite element methods to approximate PDEs arising from electromagnetics/magnetostatics. In addition to the contributions in numerical PDE methods, this project proposes the first theoretical analysis for the attention neural architecture under a Hilbertian framework, and has applied the Transformer neural network to the PDE operator learning problem for the first time.

The new paradigm of the interface virtual element methods, including both discretizations and solver design strategy, has a broader impact for practitioners of multiphysics simulations. Taking advantage of some unique traits of VEM, the resulting methods yield efficient and robust approximations to the physical quantities needed. The proposed virtual element methods can handily be incorporated into more advanced software for complex multiphysics simulations, given the publicly available implementations. Source codes for publications are provided on GitHub or CodeOcean, to promote reproducibility among the scientific computing community. Transformer neural network is the backbone of all state-of-art models in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Computer Vision (CV), such as GPT, and the variational form interpretation of the Petrov-Galerkin projection proposed could provide insights into how to design and improve data-driven models.

The PI disseminated these results through refereed journal and conference publications, and preprints may be found on the open-access repository arXiv. In addition, the PI presented his findings at several domestic conferences.

The PI co-supervised three Ph.D. students during the project's duration. The project was also the basis of two student?s Ph.D. thesis.
